comments.html: You're the best Ivan!  Perl ran a lot of networks, let's be honest...
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
I try to separate "SDN" and "Network Automation." Automation has been around for decades now and I'd put this one under that, not necessarily SDN, even though people seem to like to spin it as SDN. SDN to me is driven by dynamic variables including applications.

Now back in the mid-90s we did have RADIUS options controlling things like L2TP tunnels to redirect users to a certain path like walled gardens, web-filtering boxes, etc. Maybe you could call that SDN? Still a tortured interpretation IMHO.
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html: "We Had SDN in 1993 … and it didn´t make it" ;)
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
We also had "cloud" computing in 1993-1995 Novell teamed up with AT&T to host Novell servers and lotus notes service from AT&T connected via frame relay.
Worked then but slow fat protocol over thin VCs.. But it was touted in the old rags back then. How funny,
comments.name: jsicuran

comments.html: There is a point here, this stuff is not "new". What about GSMP, MSF, FORCES, and even MEGAGO (diff. use context), etc. 10+years ago efforts, some of which are still superior in many ways (in terms both architecture, functionality and  to the current "new" OpenFlow does it all for you BS ? For Stanford folks to market this as a new invention of theirs and take credit is ignorant and irresponsible - folks like Nick Mckeowns surely remember the previous attempts. The key problem with the industry is that everyone seems to have a self appointed "right" to come up with "new" protocol/interfaces for old things, and call it solution. No wonder folks get frustrated on the height of the RFC and other spec pile.
comments.name: Anonymous
